title: HMS Matabele (F26)
text:
HMS "Matabele" was a <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> that saw service in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, being sunk by a <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> on 17 January 1942. She has been the only ship of the Royal Navy to bear the name "Matabele", which in common with the other ships of the Tribal class, was named after an ethnic group of the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>. In this case, this was the Anglicisation of the <a href="Ndebele%20people%20%28Zimbabwe%29">Ndebele people</a> of <a href="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>.
Description.
The Tribals were intended to counter the large destroyers being built abroad and to improve the firepower of the existing destroyer <a href="flotilla">flotilla</a>s and were thus significantly larger and more heavily armed than the preceding . The ships displaced at <a href="Displacement%20%28ship%29">standard</a> load and at <a href="deep%20load">deep load</a>. They had an <a href="length%20overall">overall length</a> of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draught</a> of . The destroyers were powered by two <a href="Parsons%20Marine%20Steam%20Turbine%20Company">Parsons</a> geared <a href="steam%20turbine">steam turbine</a>s, each driving one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a> using steam provided by three <a href="Admiralty%20three-drum%20boiler">Admiralty three-drum boiler</a>s. The turbines developed a total of and gave a maximum speed of . During her <a href="sea%20trial">sea trial</a>s "Matabele" made from at a displacement of . The ships carried enough <a href="fuel%20oil">fuel oil</a> to give them a range of at . The ships' complement consisted of 190 officers and <a href="naval%20rating">ratings</a>, although the <a href="flotilla%20leader">flotilla leader</a>s carried an extra 20 officers and men consisting of the <a href="Captain%20%28D%29">Captain (D)</a> and his staff.
The primary armament of the Tribal-class destroyers was eight <a href="List%20of%20British%20ordnance%20terms%23QF">quick-firing (QF)</a> <a href="4.7%20inch%20QF%20Mark%20XII">4.7-inch (120 mm) Mark XII guns</a> in four <a href="superfiring">superfiring</a> twin-gun mounts, one pair each fore and aft of the <a href="superstructure">superstructure</a>, designated 'A', 'B', 'X', and 'Y' from front to rear. The mounts had a maximum <a href="elevation%20%28ballistics%29">elevation</a> of 40°. For <a href="Anti-aircraft%20warfare">anti-aircraft (AA)</a> defence, they carried a single quadruple mount for the <a href="QF%202%20pounder%20naval%20gun">QF two-pounder Mk II</a> "pom-pom" gun and two quadruple mounts for the <a href="Vickers%20.50%20machine%20gun">0.5-inch (12.7 mm) Mark III</a> <a href="machine%20gun">machine gun</a>. Low-angle fire for the main guns was controlled by the <a href="Director%20%28military%29">director-control tower (DCT)</a> on the <a href="bridge%20%28nautical%29">bridge</a> roof that fed data acquired by it and the <a href="rangefinder">rangefinder</a> on the Mk II Rangefinder/Director directly aft of the DCT to an analogue <a href="mechanical%20computer">mechanical computer</a>, the Mk I <a href="Admiralty%20Fire%20Control%20Clock">Admiralty Fire Control Clock</a>. Anti-aircraft fire for the main guns was controlled by the Rangefinder/Director which sent data to the mechanical <a href="Fuze%20Keeping%20Clock">Fuze Keeping Clock</a>.
The ships were fitted with a single above-water quadruple mount for <a href="British%2021-inch%20torpedo"></a> torpedoes. The Tribals were not intended as anti-submarine ships, but they were provided with <a href="ASDIC">ASDIC</a>, one <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a> rack and two throwers for self-defence, although the throwers were not mounted in all ships; Twenty depth charges was the peacetime allotment, but this increased to 30 during wartime.
Wartime modifications.
Heavy losses to <a href="Nazi%20Germany">German</a> air attack during the <a href="Norwegian%20Campaign">Norwegian Campaign</a> demonstrated the ineffectiveness of the Tribals' anti-aircraft suite and the RN decided in May 1940 to replace 'X' mount with two <a href="QF%204%20inch%20Mk%20XVI%20naval%20gun">QF Mark XVI</a> <a href="dual-purpose%20gun">dual-purpose gun</a>s in a twin-gun mount. To better control the guns, the existing rangefinder/director was modified to accept a <a href="Type%20285%20radar">Type 285</a> <a href="fire-control%20radar">gunnery radar</a> as they became available. The number of depth charges was increased to 46 early in the war, and still more were added later. To increase the firing arcs of the AA guns, the rear <a href="funnel%20%28ship%29">funnel</a> was shortened and the <a href="mainmast">mainmast</a> was reduced to a short pole mast.
Construction and career.
Authorized as one of nine Tribal-class destroyers under the 1936 Naval Estimates, "Matabele" has been the first and only ship of her name to serve in the Royal Navy. The ship was ordered on 19 June 1936 from <a href="Scotts%20Shipbuilding%20and%20Engineering%20Company">Scotts Shipbuilding and Engineering Company</a> and was <a href="laid%20down">laid down</a> on 1 October at the company's <a href="Greenock">Greenock</a> <a href="shipyard">shipyard</a>. <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">Launched</a> on 6 October 1937, "Matabele" was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 25 January 1939 at a cost of <a href="pound%20sterling">£</a>342,005 which excluded weapons and communications outfits furnished by the <a href="British%20Admiralty">Admiralty</a>.
She was initially assigned to the 2nd Tribal Destroyer Flotilla of the <a href="Home%20Fleet">Home Fleet</a>, which was renamed the <a href="6th%20Destroyer%20Flotilla">6th Destroyer Flotilla</a> in April 1939.
Her early career with the flotilla mostly involved port visits and exercises. On 12 May she escorted the <a href="ocean%20liner">ocean liner</a> through the <a href="English%20Channel">English Channel</a>. "Empress of Australia" was carrying <a href="George%20VI">King George VI</a> and <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20The%20Queen%20Mother">Queen Elizabeth</a> on their <a href="Royal%20tours%20of%20Canada">Royal Tour</a> to <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. In June "Matabele" was assigned to assist in rescue operations for the stricken <a href="submarine">submarine</a> which had sunk during builder's trials in <a href="Liverpool%20Bay">Liverpool Bay</a>. On her release from these duties, "Matabele" resumed her Home Fleet programme with the Flotilla. With war looming, she took up her Home Fleet war station in August, and was deployed for interception and anti-submarine patrol in Home waters.
World War II.
On the outbreak of the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, "Matabele" carried out duties including the interception of German shipping attempting to return to German ports and <a href="commerce%20raider">commerce raider</a>s on passage to attack British shipping in the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, as well as patrols to intercept U-boats operating in Home waters. On 25 September she was deployed with sisters and to search for the submarine , which had been badly damaged during a patrol in <a href="Heligoland%20Bight">Heligoland Bight</a>. Having successfully made contact with "Spearfish" on 26 September, they escorted her back to the UK under the cover of major warships of the Home Fleet.
Through October to December, "Matabele" carried out patrols to intercept German ships on passage for attacks on coastal shipping, as well as heading into the Atlantic Ocean for attacks on convoys or for submarine <a href="minelayer">minelayer</a>s. She also carried out screening duties for major Home Fleet warships. In January and February 1940 she was under repair at <a href="HMNB%20Devonport">HMNB Devonport</a> for work which included the replacement of turbine blades, damaged due to excess stress during high speed steaming in inclement weather, and the installation of <a href="de-gaussing">de-gaussing</a> equipment for protection against magnetic <a href="naval%20mine">mines</a>. She returned to active service in March, and took part in convoy escorts to and from Norway, as well as sweeps to intercept German warships. Whilst carrying out these duties, "Matabele" came under heavy air attacks on 13 April, and again on 16 April, but escaped undamaged. On 17 April she escorted the <a href="cruiser">cruiser</a>s and to <a href="Bod%C3%B8">Bodø</a>. On 18 April she ran aground on Foksen shoal, but managed to re-float with damage to her structure. "Effingham" also ran aground, but suffered serious damage. "Matabele" took off troops and equipment from the stricken cruiser, after which "Matabele" scuttled "Effingam" with torpedoes and gunfire.
She continued supporting operations off Norway , and then returned to the UK at the end of May for repairs and a refit at <a href="Falmouth%2C%20Cornwall">Falmouth</a>. This work lasted until July and involved the replacement of her twin 4.7-inch mounting in "X" position aft with a twin 4 inch HA mounting to improve her defence against air attacks. She returned to active service after post refit trials on 19 August. She continued to serve in Home waters and off Norway. On 22 October she and "Somali" attacked a convoy off <a href="%C3%85ndalsnes">Åndalsnes</a> and on 23 October she. "Somali" and "Punjabi" sank the German <a href="weather%20ship">weather ship</a> off <a href="Stad%20%28peninsula%29">Stadlandet</a>. "Matabele" sank a <a href="Coastal%20trading%20vessel">coaster</a>. November and December were spent operating out of <a href="Scapa%20Flow">Scapa Flow</a>, including forming part of a screen for the search for the German raider which had been reported on passage to attack the <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Atlantic">Atlantic convoys</a>.
In January 1941 she screened minelaying operations off Norway and on 16 January she escorted the <a href="battleship">battleship</a> , then on passage to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> carrying <a href="E.%20F.%20L.%20Wood%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Halifax">Lord Halifax</a> and senior defence personnel, through the <a href="Western%20Approaches">North Western Approaches</a>. Further screening of minelaying operations followed. In March she began to escort convoys, but entered refit again in <a href="Vickers-Armstrong">Vickers-Armstrong</a>'s <a href="Barrow-in-Furness">Barrow-in-Furness</a> yards on 11 April. This lasted until May and consisted of the removal of the mainmast and the top of the after funnel to improve the arcs of fire for her close range weapons. A Type 286M <a href="radar">radar</a> was also fitted. On her departure from Barrow on 5 June to rejoin the fleet, she grounded and sustained major damage to her underwater fittings, including her shaft brackets and propellers. She returned to Barrow for repairs, which lasted until mid August.
On 30 August she was deployed with the <a href="aircraft%20carrier">aircraft carrier</a> , the cruiser and the destroyers "Punjabi" and "Somali" on a mission to deliver <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">RAF</a> equipment and personnel to North Russia to support Soviet military operations after the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> had entered the war. The operation was completed successfully and the ships returned to Scapa Flow on 15 November. "Matabele" spent October to December on patrol, and screening operations off Norway.
Sinking.
In January 1942 she formed the screen, with "Somali", for the cruiser on <a href="Convoy%20PQ%208">Convoy PQ 8</a> from <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a> to <a href="Murmansk">Murmansk</a>. The convoy of eight merchant ships plus escorts departed on 11 January, and came under <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> attack on 17 January one day short of their destination by under the command of "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" Burkhard Hackländer. The first sunk was the Russian trawler "RT-68 Enisej" at 6.32am. That evening the merchant ship "Harmatis" was hit at 6.46pm by a single torpedo and taken in tow by the minesweeper HMS "Speedwell", with the "Matabele" providing escort as the rest of the convoy continued on ahead. "U-454" was able to manoeuvre into a suitable position and at 10.21pm fired and hit the "Matabele" in the stern area with a single torpedo which detonated a magazine, causing the destroyer to sink in less than two minutes at position 69.21N 35.24E.
Unable to free their <a href="Carley%20float">Carley life raft</a>s the surviving crew were forced to jump overboard into the freezing sea, with many being killed when the "Matabele"s depth charges exploded as the ship sank. The ice-cold sea temperatures then caused further loss of life to such an extent that out of her complement of 238 only two survived of the four that were rescued up by the <a href="minesweeper">minesweeper</a> .
